introduction.p: One very useful application of implicit differentiation is to find the derivatives of inverse functions. We have already used this approach to find the derivative of the inverse of the exponential function the logarithm.

We are now going to consider the problem of finding the derivatives of the inverses of trigonometric functions. Now is a very good time to go back and reread Section on inverse functions especially Definition. Most importantly, given a function f(x), its inverse function f^{-1}(x) only exists, with domain D, when f(x) passes the horizontal line test, which says that for each Y in D the horizontal line y=Y intersects the graph y=f(x) exactly once. (That is, f(x) is a one-to-one function.)
Let us start by playing with the sine function and determine how to restrict the domain of \sin x so that its inverse function exists.

example.title: The inverse of \sin x
example.p: Let y=f(x)=\sin(x). We would like to find the inverse function which takes y and returns to us a unique x-value so that \sin(x)=y.

For each real number Y, the number of x-values that obey \sin(x)=Y, is exactly the number of times the horizontal straight line y=Y intersects the graph of \sin(x).
When -1\le Y\le 1, the horizontal line intersects the graph infinitely many times. This is illustrated in the figure above by the line y=0.3.
On the other hand, when Y \lt -1 or Y \gt 1, the line y=Y never intersects the graph of \sin(x). This is illustrated in the figure above by the line y=-1.2.
This is exactly the horizontal line test and it shows that the sine function is not one-to-one.

As we saw above when |Y| \gt 1 no x obeys \sin(x)=Y and, for each -1\le Y\le 1, the line y=Y (illustrated in the figure above with y=0.3) crosses the curve y=\sin(x) infinitely many times, so that there are infinitely many x's that obey f(x)=\sin x=Y. However exactly one of those crossings (the dot in the figure) has -\frac{\pi}{2}\le x \le\frac{\pi}{2}.

Note that many texts will use \sin^{-1}(x) to denote arcsine, however we will use \arcsin(x) since we feel that it is clearer The main reason being that people frequently confuse \sin^{-1} (x) with (\sin(x))^{-1} = \frac{1}{\sin x}. We feel that prepending the prefix arc less likely to lead to such confusion. The notations \textrm{asin}(x) and \textrm{Arcsin}(x) are also used.; the reader should recognise both.

example.title: More on the inverse of \sin x
example.p: It looks like the graph of \sin x is symmetric about x=\frac{\pi}{2}. The mathematical way to say that the graph of \sin x is symmetric about x=\frac{\pi}{2} is \sin(\frac{\pi}{2}-\theta)= \sin(\frac{\pi}{2}+\theta) for all \theta. That is indeed true Indeed both are equal to \cos \theta. You can see this by playing with the trig identities in Appendix. .

Now \frac{11\pi}{16}=\frac{\pi}{2} +\frac{3\pi}{16} so
\sin\Big(\frac{11\pi}{16}\Big) =\sin\Big(\frac{\pi}{2}+\frac{3\pi}{16}\Big) =\sin\Big(\frac{\pi}{2}-\frac{3\pi}{16}\Big) =\sin\Big(\frac{5\pi}{16}\Big)
and, since \frac{5\pi}{16} is indeed between -\frac{\pi}{2} and \frac{\pi}{2},
\arcsin\Big(\sin\Big(\frac{11\pi}{16}\Big)\Big) =\frac{5\pi}{16}\qquad\Big(\text{and not $\frac{11\pi}{16}$}\Big).

subsection.title: Derivatives of Inverse Trig Functions
subsection.p:
Now that we have explored the arcsine function we are ready to find its derivative. Lets call
\arcsin(x) &= \theta(x),
so that the derivative we are seeking is \diff{\theta}{x}. The above equation is (after taking sine of both sides) equivalent to
\sin(\theta) &= x
Now differentiate this using implicit differentiation (we just have to remember that \theta varies with x and use the chain rule carefully):
\cos(\theta) \cdot \diff{\theta}{x} &= 1
\diff{\theta}{x} &= \frac{1}{\cos(\theta)} & \text{substitute $\theta = \arcsin x$}
\diff{}{x} \arcsin x &= \frac{1}{\cos(\arcsin x)}
This doesn't look too bad, but it's not really very satisfying because the right hand side is expressed in terms of \arcsin(x) and we do not have an explicit formula for \arcsin(x).

However even without an explicit formula for \arcsin(x), it is a simple matter to get an explicit formula for \cos\big(\arcsin(x)\big), which is all we need. Just draw a rightangled triangle with one angle being \arcsin(x). This is done in the figure below The figure is drawn for the case that 0\le\arcsin(x)\le\frac{\pi}{2}. Virtually the same argument works for the case -\frac{\pi}{2}\le\arcsin(x)\le 0.
The definitions for \arccos, \arctan and \arccot are developed in the same way. Here are the graphs that are used.

The definitions for the remaining two inverse trigonometric functions may also be developed in the same wayIn fact, there are two different widely used definitions of \arcsec x. Under our definition, below, \theta=\arcsec x takes values in 0\le\theta\le\pi. Some people, perfectly legitimately, define \theta=\arcsec x to take values in the union of 0\le \theta\lt\frac{\pi}{2} and \pi\le\theta\lt\frac{3\pi}{2}. Our definition has the advantage of simplicity. The other definition eliminates absolute values in some computations. Similarly there are two different widely used definitions of \arccsc x.One could also define \arccot(x)=\arctan(1/x). We have chosen not to do so, because the definition we have chosen is both continuous and standard.. But it's a little easier to use
\csc x=\frac{1}{\sin x} \qquad \sec x=\frac{1}{\cos x}

example.title: The derivative of \arccos x
example.p:
To find the derivative of \arccos we can follow the same steps:
Write \arccos(x) =\theta(x) so that \cos\theta = x and the desired derivative is \diff{\theta}{x}.
Differentiate implicitly, remembering that \theta is a function of x:
-\sin\theta \diff{\theta}{x} &= 1
\diff{\theta}{x} &= -\frac{1}{\sin\theta}
\diff{}{x}\arccos x &= -\frac{1}{\sin(\arccos x)}.
To simplify this expression, again draw the relevant triangle
from which we see
\sin(\arccos x) = \sin\theta &= \sqrt{1-x^2}.
Thus
\diff{}{x}\arccos x &= -\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}.

example.title: The derivative of \arctan x
example.p:
Very similar steps give the derivative of \arctan x:
Start with \theta = \arctan x, so \tan \theta = x.
Differentiate implicitly:
\sec^2 \theta \diff{\theta}{x} &= 1
\diff{\theta}{x} &= \frac{1}{\sec^2 \theta} = \cos^2 \theta
\diff{}{x}\arctan x &= \cos^2(\arctan x).
To simplify this expression, we draw the relevant triangle
from which we see
\cos^2(\arctan x) = \cos^2\theta = \frac{1}{1+x^2}
Thus
\diff{}{x}\arctan x &= \frac{1}{1+x^2}.

An almost identical computation gives the derivative of \arccot x:
Start with \theta = \arccot x, so \cot \theta = x.
Differentiate implicitly:
-\csc^2 \theta \diff{\theta}{x} &= 1
\diff{}{x}\arccot x = \diff{\theta}{x} &= -\frac{1}{\csc^2 \theta} = -\sin^2 \theta = -\frac{1}{1+x^2}

example.title: The derivative of \arccsc x
example.p:
In the same way we can find the derivative of the remaining inverse trig function. We just use its definition, a derivative we already know and the chain rule.
\diff{}{x} \arcsec(x) = \diff{}{x} \arccos\Big(\frac{1}{x}\Big) =-\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{1}{x^2}}}\cdot\Big(-\frac{1}{x^2}\Big) =\frac{1}{|x|\sqrt{x^2-1}}
